revision.comment: /* Diameter and albedo */ The mean diameter has to be less than the widest diameter; it appears the decimal point was omitted.

{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2015 HM|10}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2015 HM|10}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = | image_size = | caption = | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Dark Energy Camera|DeCam]]–[[The Dark Energy Survey|DES]] | discovery_site = [[Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory|Cerro Tololo Obs.]] | discovered = 19 April 2015 | mpc_name = {{mp|2015 HM|10}} | alt_names = | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]] 
[[Amor asteroids|Amor]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 3 | observation_arc = 0.39 yr (141 days) | aphelion = 4.0411 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 1.0085 AU | semimajor = 2.5248 AU | eccentricity = 0.6006 | period = 4.01 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (1,465 days) | mean_anomaly = 195.53[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.2457|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 1.4699° | asc_node = 283.27° | arg_peri = 353.48° | moid = 0.0022 AU{{·}}0.9 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]] | dimensions = 0.057 km {{small|(calculated)}} | rotation = {{val|0.3761|0.0001}} [[Hour|h]]
{{val|0.3763|0.0003}} h | albedo = 0.20 {{small|(assumed)}} | spectral_type = [[S-type asteroid|S]] {{small|(assumed)}} | abs_magnitude = 23.6 }} '''{{mp|2015 HM|10}}''' is an irregular shaped [[asteroid]] and sub-kilometer [[near-Earth object]] that passed near the Earth on 7 July 2015, at a distance of 442,000 kilometers or 1.15 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]]. First observed on 19 April 2015, by astronomers of [[The Dark Energy Survey]] at [[Cerro Tololo Observatory]] in Chile, the asteroid measures approximately 60 meters in diameter and is classified as a member of the [[Apollo asteroids|Apollo]] and [[Amor asteroids|Amor]] group, respectively. It is a [[List of fast rotators (minor planets)|fast rotator]] with a [[rotation period]] of 22.6 minutes. == Discovery == It was first observed on 19 April 2015, by astronomers of [[The Dark Energy Survey]], using the [[Dark Energy Camera]] (DECam, {{small|[[IAU code#W84|W84]]}}) mounted on the [[Victor M. Blanco Telescope]] located at [[Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory]] in Chile. == Orbit and classification == {{mp|2015 HM|10}} has been classified as a [[near-Earth object]] of the [[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]] and [[Amor asteroids|Amor]] group, respectively. It orbits the Sun at a distance of 1.0–4.0 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 4.01 years (1,465 days). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.60 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 1[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. The body's [[observation arc]] begins with a [[precovery]] taken at Cerro Tololo, the night prior to its official first observation. === Close encounters === {{mp|2015 HM|10}} has an Earth [[minimum orbital intersection distance]] of {{convert |0.0022 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3}} which corresponds to 0.9 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]]. On 7 July 2015, it passed Earth at {{convert |0.00295299 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3}}, or 1.15 lunar distances. On the following day, it passed the Moon at {{convert |0.00276|AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3}}. This was the asteroid’s closest approach to Earth until at least 2419. == Physical characteristics == {{mp|2015 HM|10}} is an assumed stony [[S-type asteroid]]. === Rotation and shape === During 2015, two rotational [[lightcurve]]s of {{mp|2015 HM|10}} were obtained from [[Photometry (astronomy)|photometric]] observations by [[Brian D. Warner|Brian Warner]] at the Palmer Divide Station ({{small|[[IAU code#U82|U82]]}}) in California and by astronomers of the Mission Accessible Near-Earth Objects Survey (MANOS). Lightcurve analysis gave a [[rotation period]] of 0.3761 and 0.3763 hours (22.6 minutes) with a brightness amplitude of 1.50 and 1.29 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=3/3-]]}}), indicative of a non-spheroidal shape. It is among the [[List of fast rotators (minor planets)|fastest rotator]]s known to exists. In July 2015, high-resolution images of {{mp|2015 HM|10}} were obtained from [[Radiometry|radiometric]] observations made with the [[Very Long Baseline Array]], the [[Arecibo Observatory]], and the 34 and 70-meter antennas at [[Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex|Goldstone]]. These observations confirmed the body's short rotation period and complex and irregular, and revealed, that it has a long-axis extent of 80–100 meters with an equatorial aspect ratio of about 2:1. Any significant non-principal axis rotation, commonly known as "tumbling" could be ruled out. The radar images also showed angular features up to approximately 30 meters across, with a cluster of radar-bright pixels following its rotation, and consistent with a high standing, 15 to 20 meters wide feature. === Diameter and albedo === The ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' assumes a standard albedo for stony asteroids of 0.20 and calculates a mean-diameter of 57.0 meters based on an [[absolute magnitude]] of 23.6. At its widest point, the object is 80 meters long. == Numbering and naming == As of 2017, this [[minor planet]] has neither been numbered nor named. == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2015-09-06 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2015 HM10) |url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3717042 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 17 October 2017}} {{cite web |title = 2015 HM10 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2015+HM10 |accessdate = 17 October 2017}} {{cite web |author1 = National Radio Astronomy Observatory |title = Astronomy summer school radar observations shine new light on near-earth asteroid |date = 14 July 2015 |url = http://phys.org/news/2015-07-astronomy-summer-school-radar-near-earth.html |accessdate = 17 October 2017}} {{Cite journal |display-authors = 6 |first1 = Michael W. |last1 = Busch |first2 = Lance A. M. |last2 = Benner |first3 = Shantanu P. |last3 = Naidu |first4 = Marina |last4 = Brozovic |first5 = James E. |last5 = Richardson |first6 = Edgard G. |last6 = Rivera-Valentin |first7 = Patrick A. |last7 = Taylor |first8 = H. Alyson |last8 = Ford |first9 = Frank D. |last9 = Ghigo |first10 = Jon D. |last10 = Giorgini |first11 = Joseph S. |last11 = Jao |first12 = Lawrence |last12 = Teitelbaum |date = November 2015 |title = Asteroids With Tensile Strength: The Case of 2015 HM10 |url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?bibcode=2015DPS....4740205B |journal = American Astronomical Society |bibcode = 2015DPS....4740205B |access-date= 17 October 2017}} {{cite web |title = LCDB Data for (2015 HM10) |publisher = Asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB) |url = http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/GenerateALCDEFPage_Local.php?AstInfo=0%7C2015+HM10 |accessdate = 17 October 2017}} {{Cite journal |first1 = Brian D. |last1 = Warner |first2 = William H. |last2 = Ryan |date = January 2016 |title = Lightcurve Analysis of NEA 2015 HM10 |url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/bib_query?bibcode=2016MPBu...43...30W |journal = The Minor Planet Bulletin |volume = 43 |issue = 1 |pages = 30–31 |issn = 1052-8091 |bibcode = 2016MPBu...43...30W |access-date= 17 October 2017}} {{Cite journal |display-authors = 6 |first1 = A. |last1 = Thirouin |first2 = N. |last2 = Moskovitz |first3 = R. P. |last3 = Binzel |first4 = E. |last4 = Christensen |first5 = F. E. |last5 = DeMeo |first6 = M. J. |last6 = Person |first7 = D. |last7 = Polishook |first8 = C. A. |last8 = Thomas |first9 = D. |last9 = Trilling |first10 = M. |last10 = Willman |first11 = M. |last11 = Hinkle |first12 = B. |last12 = Burt |first13 = D. |last13 = Avner |first14 = F. J. |last14 = Aceituno |date = December 2016 |title = The Mission Accessible Near-Earth Objects Survey (MANOS): First Photometric Results |url = https://arxiv.org/pdf/1607.03517.pdf |journal = The Astronomical Journal |volume = 152 |issue = 6 |page = 31 |bibcode = 2016AJ....152..163T |doi = 10.3847/0004-6256/152/6/163 |arxiv = 1607.03517 |access-date= 17 October 2017}} }} == External links == * [https://www.lpi.usra.edu/nuggets/2015/nugget_neo_nea_2015-08-14.pdf Close Pass of Near-Earth Asteroid 2015 HM10], ''Lunar and Planetary Institute'' * [http://www.minorplanet.info/PHP/lcdbsummaryquery.php Asteroid Lightcurve Database (LCDB)], query form ([http://www.minorplanet.info/lightcurvedatabase.html info]) * {{NeoDys|2015HM10}} * {{JPL small body|id=3717042}} {{use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2015 HM10}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Amor asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2015|20150707]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2015|20150419]]

revision.text:
The '''[[Bayer designation]]s''' "A Centauri" and "a Centauri" represent different objects, as does "α Centauri"
* "[[A Centauri]]" (HD 100673) * "a Centauri" ([[V761 Centauri]]) * "α Centauri" -- [[Alpha Centauri]] (Rigel Kentaurus) ** "α<sup>1</sup> Centauri" -- [[Alpha Centauri A]] (HD 128620) ** "α<sup>2</sup> Centauri" -- [[Alpha Centauri B]] (HD 128621)
==See also== * [[Alpha Centauri (disambiguation)]] * [[1 Centauri]]

{{Infobox person | name = Charles Joseph Lambert | image = Carlos José Lambert.jpg | imagesize = 300px | caption = | birth_name = Carlos José Lambert | birth_date = 1826 | birth_place = [[La Serena, Chile]] | death_date = 11 July 1888 | death_place = [[Cowes]], [[Isle of Wight]], [[England]] | occupation = Mining engineer
Mining entrepreneur | language = |party = |parents = {{ill|Charles Saint Lambert|es|Carlos Lambert}} {{right|''1793-1876''}}
_____ Spears |spouse = Susan Bath/Lambert {{right|''1829-1898''}} |alma_mater = | children =1. Catherine Susan Lambert/Clutterbuck
{{right|''1849-1915''}}
2. Charles L. Lambert
{{right|''1851-1874''}}
3. Janet Spears Lambert/Black
{{right|''1852-?''}}
4. Henry Bath Lambert
{{right|''1853-1892''}}
5. Margaret Lambert
{{right|''1856-1892''}}
6. Robert Spears Lambert
{{right|''1858-1902''}}
7. Helen Mark Lambert/Levett
{{right|''1864-?''}}
8. Beatrice Kate Lambert
{{right|''?-?''}}9. George Maximiano Lambert
{{right|''1868-1891''}}
10. William Stanley Lambert
{{right|''1869-1907''}} | nationality = }} '''Charles Joseph Lambert''' / '''Carlos José Lambert''' (1826 - 1888) was a [[Chile|Chilean]]-born mining entrepreneur and engineer.{{cite book|title=Gaceta de los tribunales|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGQvAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA87| year=1865|page=87}} ==Life== ===Family provenance and early years=== Carlos José Lambert is believed to have been born in or near [[La Serena, Chile|La Serena]]. However, surviving records of his birth and baptism have not been identified. (In the 1820s members of the European expatriate community frequently attended to baptismal formalities not in [[Roman Catholic]] churches onshore, but on British ships moored offshore.) His father {{ill|Charles Saint Lambert|es|Carlos Lambert}} (1793-1876), was a prominent, and increasingly prosperous, mining entrepreneur who had been born in [[Strasbourg]] and emigrated to [[Chile]] in 1817.{{cite web| url=http://www.henrybath.com/assets/_files/documents/jun_11/HENRYBATH__1308588481_Complete_Henry_Bath_History.pdf| date=October 2010| author=Mike Jackson| title=Henry Bath & Son - A Company and family History| accessdate=1 November 2016}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He established contacts in England, acquired British nationality and returned to Chile in 1823 as a representative of a British company called the "Chilean Mining Association", which later went bankrupt.{{cite web|url=http://revistahistoria.uc.cl/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/mayo-collier-couyoumdjian-32.pdf|author1=John Mayo and Simon Collier (authors)|author2=Juan Ricardo Couyoumdjian (translator into Spanish - currently the only version of the text location online)|title=Mining in Chile's Norte Chico. |work=Journal of Charles Lambert. 1825-1830, Dellplain Latin American Studies N°36. Westview Press, Boulder. Colorado, |date=1998|publisher=Publication of the Instituto de Historia, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile|accessdate=1 November 2016}} The career of Charles Saint Lambert (the father) continued to prosper, however. Little is known of his mother, who is frequently described as "English", although at least one source indicates that she was born further north, in [[Scotland]].{{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/n-n-Spears/6000000030736249152|title=n.n. Spears|publisher=Geni.com|accessdate=1 November 2011}} Charles Joseph Lambert spent much of his childhood in Britain. Around 1840 his father relocated the family base to [[Swansea]] which was becoming the principal smelting centre for industrial scale copper (and other) ores from [[Chile]], following the exhaustion of principal mines closer to hand in Cornwall. In Swansea he was involved in regular commercial negotiations with Edward Bath, scion of a major industrial family in the area (and subsequently his brother-in-law twice over). In practice, he appears to have divided his time between Chile and South Wales throughout his working life. ===Activities in Chile=== As a mining engineer he exploited new copper-smelting technology employing "coal-using reverbatory furnaces"{{cite book|author=W.E Minchinton|title=Industrial South Wales 1750-1914: Essays in Welsh Economic History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hXD_AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA141|date=5 November 2013| publisher=Routledge| isbn=978-1-136-61779-9|page=141}} which his father had introduced to Chile in 1848,{{cite book|title=Mining in Chile's Norte Chico: Journal of Charles Lambert, 1825-1830 (Dellplain Latin American Studies)| author1=John Mayo |author2=Simon Collier |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Mining-Chiles-Norte-Chico-1825-1830/dp/0813335841| publisher=Westview Press Inc|isbn=978-0-813-33584-1}} and which at this stage gave an important competitive advantage. He was also active as a farmer, with an extensive property in the valley of the [[Rapel River]], centred on a Welsh style farmhouse. This farm also included silver deposits which he exploited. He actively promoted the construction of the railway connecting [[La Serena, Chile|La Serena]] with the port of [[Coquimbo]], taking a significant shareholding in the project, which also linked up two of the family's smelting locations. He promoted the exploitation of sheep imported from [[England]] and [[Australia]], as well as raising sheep himself. In La Serena has also backed the drainage project, proposing the construction of a canal to divert water from the [[Elqui River]] to an outlet near the port which would drain the coastal area of the Bay of Coquimbo. At the start of the [[War of the Pacific|Pacific War]] in 1879 he is identified as the originator of fortifications along the Bay of Coquimbo.{{cite web|title=Fuerte Coquimbo|url=http://fuertecoquimbo.jimdo.com/antecedentes/|publisher= Jaime Patricio Espejo Rojas|accessdate=1 November 2016}} This involved (at least) three gun emplacements covering the bay. There were good strategic reasons to protect the port in order to avoid the interruption of the transport of ores from the Lambert mines to the industrial processing plants in [[Swansea]] and to prevent an attack on the domestic smelting works at "La Compañía", a couple of kilometers inland from the bay. It was thought likely that Peruvian forces would attempt to paralyse the mining industry in the region which was seen as vital to sustaining the economy in wartime. ===Philanthropy=== Lambert was an active philanthropist, funding the construction and operation of hospitals in [[La Serena, Chile|La Serena]] and [[Vicuña, Chile|Vicuña]]. He funded the health commission to combat cholera and smallpox. At Christmas he was in the habit of appearing on the city streets accompanied by his family loaded with parcels for distribution to the poor families of La Serena. ===Round the world in 713 days=== On 5 May 1880, embarking from [[Cowes]] on the [[Isle of Wight]] ([[England]]), Charles Joseph Lambert set sail aboard the company yacht for a round the world trip, accompanied by his wife, their four youngest children, a governess, a nurse, a maid, a valet, a footman, a minister of the church and an artist called Robert Prichett. Their boat, "The Wanderer", was coal powered, also capable of sail propulsion when the wind blew appropriately. Lambert kept a detailed record of the adventure in which he recorded that 1265½ [[Long ton|(British) tons]] were consumed by the voyage.{{cite web| url=https://archive.org/stream/voyagewandererf00unkngoog#page/n26/mode/1up|title="The voyage of the "Wanderer," from the journals and letters of C. and S. Lambert" |author=Gerald Young (compiler)|publisher=Macmillan, London|date=1883|accessdate=1 November 2016}} The ship was operated by 8 officers and 35 crewmen (not necessarily all at once) and the staff also included 7 ships' stewards. It may have been this voyage that inspired William Stanley Lambert, the couple's youngest son, who celebrated his eleventh and twelfth birthdays during the voyage, regarding his subsequent decision to join the [[Royal Navy|British navy]], which he did in 1885.{{cite book|author=Ed. A. B. Demaus|title=Letters from HMS Britannia: William Lambert & The Late Vic| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L26oAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA51|date=30 November 2013|publisher=Amberley Publishing Limited |isbn=978-1-4456-1256-0|pages=}} During the voyage the family were able to visit [[Hawaii]] to pay their respects to their dead son Carlos who had drowned there on 20 November 1870 while serving in the navy. The family had already erected a memorial to their dead son back home at "La Compañía" outside [[La Serena, Chile|La Serena]], and now they were able to erect another "cenotaph" with a cross near the site of his death. ===Death=== Charles Joseph Lambert himself died on 11 July 1888. He suffered "an epidemic of ‘choleric diarrhoea’" and booked a passage on a steamship to [[Liverpool]] where he spent his final months staying in an hotel beside the [[Royal Yacht Club]]. The actual death took place not in Liverpool, however, but at [[Cowes]] on the [[Isle of Wight]].{{Cite web| url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=n1duTmYW6cgg8wNLsFpGzg&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=1 November 2016|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lambert, Charles Joseph}} [[Category:People from La Serena]] [[Category:Chilean mining engineers]] [[Category:Chilean miners]] [[Category:Chilean businesspeople]] [[Category:Chilean people of French descent]] [[Category:Chilean people of British descent]] [[Category:1826 births]] [[Category:1888 deaths]] [[Category:Circumnavigators of the globe]] [[Category:Chilean sailors]]

{{About|a region of India|the region in New Zealand|Coromandel Peninsula|the town in Brazil|Coromandel, Minas Gerais}} {{More citations needed|date=May 2013}} {{Use Indian English|date=December 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{-}} [[File:India Coromandel Coast locator map.svg|thumb|350px|Districts along the Coromandel Coast]] [[File:Coromandel Coast 1753.jpg|thumb|200px|Map of the coast {{fr icon}}]] The '''Coromandel Coast''' is the southeastern coast region of the [[Indian subcontinent]], bounded by the [[Utkal Plains]] to the north, the Bay of Bengal to the east, the [[Kaveri]] delta to the south, and the [[Eastern Ghats]] to the west, extending over an area of about 22,800 square kilometres.<ref name=britannica>[https://www.britannica.com/place/Coromandel-Coast Encyclopædia Britannica entry on Coromandel Coast]</ref> Its definition can also include the northwestern coast of the island of [[Sri Lanka]].{{cn|date=November 2017}} The coast has an average elevation of 80 metres and is backed by the [[Eastern Ghats]], a chain of low, flat-topped hills.
==Etymology== Coromondel is the Dutch pronunciation of "Karimanal", a village in the Sriharikota island in the north of Pazhavercadu (Pulecat Lake).<ref>Topographic Map of India "66C/7 & 66C/11" by Survey of India</ref> Pazhavercadu (Pulecat) was an early Dutch settlement along with Masoolipatnam in present-day Andhra Pradesh. There is a Dutch Cemetery belonging to the seventeenth Century at Pulecat. It is said that the first Dutch ship stopped here for fresh drinking water, and upon asking the name of the place Karimanal was spelled as Corimondal (K replaced with C and d inserted).<ref>"http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/mag/2003/10/19/stories/2003101900280700.htm"</ref>
The land of the [[Chola dynasty]] was called ''Cholamandalam'' (சோழ மண்டலம்) in [[Tamil language|Tamil]], literally translated as ''The realm of the Cholas'', from which the Portuguese derived the name ''Coromandel''.<ref name="TheLandoftheTamuliansandItsMissions">''The Land of the Tamulians and Its Missions'', by Eduard Raimund Baierlein, James Dunning Baker</ref><ref name="South Indian Coins - Page 61">South Indian Coins – Page 61 by T. Desikachari – Coins, Indic – 1984</ref><ref name="Indian History - Page 112">Indian History – Page 112</ref><ref name="Annals of Oriental Research - Page 1">''Annals of Oriental Research'' – Page 1 by University of Madras – 1960</ref><ref name="The Periplus of the Erythræan Sea">''The Periplus of the Erythræan Sea'' by [[Wilfred Harvey Schoff]]</ref> The name could also be derived from ''Kurumandalam'', meaning ''The realm of the Kurus''.<ref>{{cite book|author=Edgar Thurston|title=The Madras Presidency with Mysore, Coorg and the Associated States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O4VLY1KcltcC&pg=PA11|year=2011|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-60068-3|page=11}}</ref>
==Description== ===Economy=== Agriculture is the mainstay of the coastal economy. Rice, pulses (legumes), sugarcane, cotton, and peanuts (groundnuts) are grown. Bananas and betel nuts are grown together with rice in the low-rainfall region of the interior. There are casuarina and coconut plantations along the coast.
Large-scale industries produce fertilizers, chemicals, film projectors, amplifiers, trucks, and automobiles. There is a [[Heavy Vehicles Factory|heavy vehicle and armoured car factory]] at Avadi and a [[Madras Atomic Power Station|nuclear power station]] at Kalpakkam.
Roads and railways linking Chennai, Cuddalore, Chidambaram, Chengalpattu, and Puducherry run parallel to the coast.
===Geography=== The coast is generally low, and punctuated by the deltas of several large rivers, including the [[Kaveri]], [[Palar River|Palar]], [[Penner River|Penner]], and [[Krishna River]], which rise in the highlands of the [[Western Ghats]] and flow across the [[Deccan Plateau|Deccan]] Plateau to drain into the [[Bay of Bengal]]. The [[alluvial plains]] created by these rivers are fertile and favour agriculture. The rivers remain dry during most of the year. There is little forest cover, but marshes, swamps, scrub woodlands, and thorny thickets are common.
The coastline forms a part of [[Coastline of Tamil Nadu|Tamil Nadu]] and [[Coastline of Andhra Pradesh|Andhra Pradesh]]. The important ports include [[Chennai]], [[Thoothukkudi]], [[Nellore]], [[Ennore]] and [[Nagapattinam]], which take advantage of their close proximity with regions rich in natural and mineral resources and good transport infrastructure.
===Climate=== The Coromandel Coast falls in the [[rain shadow]] of the [[Western Ghats]] mountain range, and receives a good deal less rainfall during the summer [[southwest monsoon]]s, which contributes heavy rainfall in the rest of India. The region averages 800 mm/year, most of which falls between October and December. The topography of the Bay of Bengal, and the staggered weather pattern prevalent during the season favours [[northeast monsoon]]s, which have a tendency to cause [[cyclone]]s and [[hurricane]]s rather than a steady precipitation. As a result, the coast is hit by inclement weather almost every year between October and January.
The high variability of rainfall patterns is also responsible for water scarcity and famine in most areas not served by the great rivers. For example, the city of Chennai is one of the driest cities in the country in terms of potable water availability, despite high percentage of moisture in the air, due to the unpredictable, seasonal nature of the monsoon.
===Flora=== The Coromandel Coast is home to the [[East Deccan dry evergreen forests]] [[ecoregion]], which runs in a narrow strip along the coast. Unlike most of the other [[Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests|tropical dry forest]] [[Biome]] regions of India, where the trees lose their leaves during the dry season, the East Deccan dry evergreen forests retain their leathery leaves year round.
The Coromandel Coast is also home to extensive [[mangrove]] forests along the low-lying coast and [[river delta]]s, and several important [[wetland]]s, notably [[Kaliveli Lake]] and [[Pulicat Lake]], that provide habitat to thousands of migrating and resident birds.
==History== [[File:Sarasa chintz.jpg|thumb|upright|Sarasa [[chintz]] from the Coromandel Coast, 17th or 18th century, made for the Japanese market. Private collection, [[Nara Prefecture]]. ]] By late 1530 the Coromandel Coast was home to three Portuguese settlements at [[Nagapattinam]], [[Dioceses of Saint Thomas of Mylapore|São Tomé de Meliapore]], and Pulicat. In the 17th and 18th centuries, the Coromandel Coast was the scene of rivalries among European powers for control of the India trade. The British established themselves at [[Fort St George]] (Madras) and [[Masulipatnam]], the [[Dutch Coromandel|Dutch]] at Pulicat, [[Sadras]] and [[Covelong]], the French at [[Pondicherry (city)|Pondicherry]], [[Karaikal]] and [[Nizampatnam]], the [[Denmark|Danish]] in [[Tharangambadi|Dansborg]] at Tharangambadi.
The Coromandel Coast supplied [[Indian Muslim]] [[eunuch]]s to the Thai palace and court of [[History of Thailand|Siam]] (modern Thailand).<ref>Peletz (2009), p. 73 {{Google books|BFXpi5ZKKF8C|Gender Pluralism: Southeast Asia Since Early Modern Times|page=73}}</ref><ref>Peletz (2009), p. 73 {{Google books|-YnQJXxspJUC|Gender Pluralism: Southeast Asia Since Early Modern Times|page=73}}</ref> The Thai at times asked eunuchs from China to visit the court in Thailand and advise them on court ritual since they held them in high regard.<ref>Peletz (2009), p. 75 {{Google books|BFXpi5ZKKF8C|Gender Pluralism: Southeast Asia Since Early Modern Times|page=75}}</ref><ref>Peletz (2009), p. 75 {{Google books|-YnQJXxspJUC|Gender Pluralism: Southeast Asia Since Early Modern Times|page=75}}</ref>
Eventually the British won out, although France retained the tiny enclaves of [[Pondicherry district|Pondichéry]] and [[Karaikal district|Karaikal]] until 1954. [[China|Chinese]] [[Lacquerware|lacquer goods]], including boxes, screens, and chests, became known as "Coromandel" goods in the 18th century, because many Chinese exports were consolidated at the Coromandel ports.
Two of the famous books on the economic history of the Coromandel Coast are ''Merchants, companies, and commerce on the Coromandel Coast, 1650–1740'' (Arasaratnam, Oxford University Press, 1986) and ''The World of the Weaver in Northern Coromandel, c.1750-c.1850'' (P. Swarnalatha, Orient Longman, 2005).
On 26 December 2004, one of the deadliest natural disasters in modern history, the [[Indian Ocean earthquake]], struck off the western coast of [[Sumatra]] (Indonesia). The [[earthquake]] and subsequent tsunami reportedly killed over 220,000 people around the rim of the [[Indian Ocean]]. The tsunami devastated the Coromandel Coast, killing many and sweeping away many coastal communities.
==Applications of the name== Four ships of the [[Royal Navy]] have borne the name {{HMS|Coromandel}} after the Indian coast. The [[Coromandel Peninsula]] in New Zealand was named after one of these ships, and the town of [[Coromandel, New Zealand]] was named after the peninsula. [[Coromandel Valley, South Australia]], and its neighbouring suburb, Coromandel East, gain their name from the ship ''[[Coromandel (1834 ship)|Coromandel]]'', which arrived in Holdfast Bay from London in 1837 with 156 English settlers. After the ship reached the shore, some of its sailors deserted, intending to remain behind in South Australia, and took refuge in the hills in the Coromandel Valley region.
A red [[nail varnish]] made by [[Chanel]] is named coromandel due to its suggestions of exoticism.{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} One of the earliest superfast trains of Indian Railways that runs between Howrah and Chennai is named [[Coromandel Express]].
In [[Slovenian language|Slovene]] the [[idiom]] ''Indija Koromandija'' (India Coromandel) means a land of plenty,<ref>Slovar slovenskega knjižnega jezika [http://bos.zrc-sazu.si/cgi/a03.exe?name=sskj_testa&expression=indija+koromandija&hs=1 "Indija Koromandija"]</ref> a promised land, a utopia where "Houses are bleached with cheese and covered with cake".<ref>[http://razvezanijezik.org/?page=indija+koromandija "Razvezani jezik" From: [http://razvezanijezik.org]</ref>
==In literature== The 1955 historical novel ''Coromandel!'' by [[John Masters]] describes a young English adventurer arriving in the 17th century at the Coromandel Coast. He is the founder of the Savage family, whose descendants live during British rule in India and appear in other books of Masters' series.
There is a well-known poem by the Indian poet and freedom fighter [[Sarojini Naidu]] titled 'Coromandel Fishers'. The little-known early 20th-century poet [[Walter J. Turner]] wrote a poem titled 'Coromandel'.
"The Courtship of the Yonghy-bonghy-bo" by [[Edward Lear]] is set on the Coast of Coromandel.
Coromandel wood is referred to by [[Dame Edith Sitwell]] in her poem "Black Mrs. Behemoth", part of "Façade". She likens the wood's grain to the rolling, curling smoke of a blown out candle. Sir Osbert Sitwell (Dame Edith's brother) composed a poem titled "On the coast of Coromandel".
''Coromandel Sea Change'' is a 1991 novel by [[Rumer Godden]] about a diverse group of guests staying at a hotel on the Coromandel coast during an election campaign.
The coast is noted in M.M. Kaye's novel ''The Far Pavilions''. A work of fiction, the lead character, Ashton Hilary Akbar Pelham-Martyn, retires to the Coromandel Coast early in the tale.
==See also== *[[Malabar Coast]] *[[Presidency of Coromandel and Bengal Settlements]]

revision.text:
[[File:Dreikanter from the Wind River Basin, Wyoming, USA. Photo by AJ Wakefield, 2012.jpg|thumbnail|A dreikanter from the Wind River Basin, Wyoming, USA. Property of Western Washington University. Photo by AJ Wakefield, 2012.]] A '''Dreikanter''' is a type of [[ventifact]] that typically forms in [[desert]] or [[periglacial]] environments due to the abrasive action of [[Saltation (geology)|blowing sand]].<ref>Wade, A. 1910. On the formation of dreikanter in desert regions. The Geological Magazine, Decade V, 7(9):394-398.</ref><ref>{{cite-efron|Трехгранники}}</ref>
Dreikanters exhibit a characteristic [[pyramid]]al shape with three wind-abrased facets. The word ''Dreikanter'' is a [[German language|German word]] meaning "three-edged."<ref>[http://climate.umn.edu/cawap/mpr/jargon.htm WeatherTalk - Jargon<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019191704/http://climate.umn.edu/cawap/mpr/jargon.htm |date=October 19, 2012 }}</ref>
Similarly, a zweikanter has two wind facets, an einkanter, has only one wind facet. <ref name=GreeleyBridges>Greeley, R., N. T. Bridges, R. O. Kuzmin, and J. E. Laity, Terrestrial analogs to wind-related features at the Viking and Pathfinder landing sites on Mars, J. Geophys. Res., 107(E1), 10.1029/2000JE001481, 2002.</ref>
Most places on the planet have several weathering processes acting at the same time, so finding good examples of Dreikanters is often difficult. Antarctica is a good location for finding such ventifacts since wind is usually the only active weathering agent. Many specimens in the Northeastern United States were formed during the Pleistocene era when the absence of vegetation made for little cover from wind-blown sediment.<ref name=dutch1>{{cite web|last=Dutch|first=Steven|title=Wind Erosion|url=http://www.uwgb.edu/dutchs/EarthSC202Slides/windslid.htm|publisher=University of Wisconsin|accessdate=10 October 2012}}</ref>
==Common features==
Some common features of Dreikanters include [[Fluting_(geology)|fluting]], high polish, sharp ridges, pits, grooves, and helical forms.<ref name=dutch1 /><ref name=GreeleyBridges /> [[image:Bradley_1930_dreikanter.jpg|right|thumb|300px| Unusually large dreikanter of granite, Sweetwater County, Wyoming. This dreikanter measures 71 cm by 46 cm deep and 37 cm wide. Photo by Bradley, W.H., USGS (1930).<ref>U.S. Geological Survey Photographic Library ( http://libraryphoto.cr.usgs.gov/ )</ref>]]
==Formation==
In areas where there is a prevailing wind, sand and debris cause a rock face to become flattened and polished. This changes the mass distribution of the rock, and may cause it to turn another surface toward the wind. If this process continues undisturbed, the resulting rock will have three distinct flattened and polished faces.<ref name=britannica1>{{cite web|title=Ventifact (stone)|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/625506/ventifact?anchor=ref166111|publisher=Britannica Online Encyclopedia|accessdate=10 October 2012}}</ref> Dreikanters generally form in dry, arid environments from hard rocks.<ref name=britannica1 />
==See also== *[[Aeolian processes]] *[[Blowout (geology)]] *[[Dune]] *[[Saltation (geology)]] *[[Yardang]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.uwgb.edu/dutchs/EarthSC202Slides/windslid.htm An image of a Dreikanter] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060616220723/http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=dreikanter1 Glossary of Meteorology] *[https://www.lbk.ars.usda.gov/wewc/biblio/bar.htm The Bibliography of Aeolian Research]

revision.text:
[[File:EF50.jpg|thumb|180px|EF50]] In the field of [[electronics]], the '''EF50''' is an early all-glass wideband [[Cut-off (electronics)#Remote cutoff|remote cutoff]] [[pentode]] designed in 1938 by [[Philips]]. It was a landmark in the development of [[vacuum tube]] technology, departing from construction ideas of the time essentially unchanged from light bulb designs.<ref>{{cite web|title=The EF50, the Tube that helped to Win the War|url=http://www.dos4ever.com/EF50/EF50.html|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref> Initially used in television receivers, it quickly gained a vital role in British [[radar]] and great efforts were made to secure a continuing supply of the device as Holland fell in [[World War II]].
The EF50 tube is a [[Tube socket#Other Loctals|9-pin Loctal]]-socket device with short internal wires to nine short chromium-iron pins, making it suitable for [[Very high frequency|Very High Frequency]] (VHF) use.<ref name="r-type1">{{cite web|title=The Famous EF50 of WW2 by Keith Thrower|url=http://www.r-type.org/articles/art-021.htm|access-date=22 May 2014}}</ref>
==History== The EF50 was preceded by [[RCA]]'s [[acorn tube|acorn]] design and several other attempts, such as the "Stahlröhre" (~steel tube) from [[Telefunken]], to reduce inductance in the wire leads, all with some disadvantages. Philips had been working since 1934–1935 on an alternative that would solve the problems of the other bases, and a design that could be produced cheaply and in large quantities. A presentation given by M.J.O. Strutt from the tube development group at Philips Research at the first "Internationale Fernseh-Tagung in Zürich" (international television conference in Zürich) described their work in September 1938. A few months later Professor J.L.H. Jonker, who had a leading role in the development of the EF50, published an internal Philips Research Technical Note, Titled: "New radio Tube Constructions". Jonker's role was confirmed decades later by Th. P. Tromp, head of radio-valve manufacturing and production: "Prof. Dr. Jonker (head of development lab of electronic valves in the mid thirties) was the originator of the EF50 and this development started as early as 1934–1935. It was, indeed ,developed in view of possible television application."<ref>{{cite web|title=letter of Th. P. Tromp to Mr Bell|url=http://www.dos4ever.com/EF50/letter_Tromp.htm|access-date=22 May 2014|author=Th.P.Tromp|year=1979}}</ref>
===Television requirements=== [[Pye Ltd.]], a leading British electronics firm of the time, had pioneered television receiver design, and in the late 1930s wanted to market receivers that would allow reception further and further from the single [[Alexandra Palace]] television transmitter.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dekker|first=Ronald|title=The EF50, the tube that helped to win the War|url=http://www.dos4ever.com/EF50/EF50.html|access-date=25 May 2014}}</ref> Encouraged by their 1937 success with a novel [[Tuned radio frequency receiver|tuned radio frequency]] (TRF) design, Pye wanted a higher quality valve than they could produce on their own, and so talked to [[Mullard]], which meant the research of Philips in Holland, plus some tweaking from Baden John Edwards and Donald Jackson from Pye (for example the metal shield),<ref>{{cite web|last=Dicker|first=Graham|title=The Secret Radar Valve the EF50 Part 1|url=http://www.philipstorr.id.au/radio/technical/EF50_1.pdf|access-date=25 May 2014}}</ref> leading to the EF50 pentode that was needed in the Pye 45 MHz [[Intermediate frequency|IF]] Strip, and created a stable television receiver that captured a good market, being able to receive transmissions at up to five times the distance than the competition.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dicker|first=Graham|title=The secret radar valve the EF50 Part 2|url=http://www.philipstorr.id.au/radio/technical/EF50_2.pdf|access-date=25 May 2014}}</ref>
===Radar uses=== [[Hugh Dowding]] had already seen the value of [[radar]] for his [[Dowding system|Air Defence system]].<ref>{{cite web|title=RADAR – The Battle Winner?|url=http://www.rafmuseum.org.uk/research/online-exhibitions/history-of-the-battle-of-britain/radar-the-battle-winner.aspx|publisher=The Royal Airforce Museum|accessdate=25 May 2014}}</ref> Developments progressed at [[Bawdsey Manor]] from the mid-1930s; the early ground-based radar chains worked well but needed to be improved in accuracy, and Dowding saw the need for an airborne radar. At Bawdsey, [[Edward George Bowen|Taffey Bowen]] had also needed a wideband [[vacuum tube|valve]] for [[Airborne Interception radar|Airborne Interception]] (AI) radar; he had just one working set. So he contacted Tom Goldup, a senior director of [[Mullard]],<ref name="r-type1"/> and "quite by chance in April or May of 1939" he heard of the Pye set from his old Professor at King's College, [[Edward Victor Appleton|Edward Appleton]]. Visiting Pye, Bowen saw scores of what he sought, their 45MHz TRF chassis using the very new EF50, which he later described as "a valve that was to play almost as important a part in the radar war as the [[Cavity magnetron|magnetron]]".<ref>{{cite book|last=Bowen|first=Edward G|title=Radar Days|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-7503-0586-0 |pages=77,231}}</ref>
===Flight from Holland=== Because the EF50 had to come from Holland, yet was vital for the RDF ([[radar]]), great efforts were made to secure a continuing supply as the risk of Holland being overrun increased. Mullard in England did not have the ability to manufacture the special glass base, for example, and just before Germany invaded Holland, a truckload with 25,000 complete EF50s and many more of their special bases were successfully sent to England.<ref name="r-type1"/> The entire EF50 production line was hurriedly relocated to Britain.<ref>{{cite web|title=EF50|url=http://www.radiomuseum.org/tubes/tube_ef50.html|access-date=25 May 2014}}</ref> On 13 May, the day before the Germans flattened Rotterdam in 1940, members of the Philips family escaped together with the Dutch government on the British [[destroyer]] [[HMS Windsor (D42)|HMS ''Windsor'']], taking with them a small wooden box containing the industrial diamond [[die (manufacturing)#Wire pulling|die]]s needed to make the fine tungsten wires in the valves.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dekker|first=Ronald|title=The EF50, the Tube that helped to Win the War|url=http://www.dos4ever.com/EF50/EF50_klein.html|access-date=25 May 2014}}</ref>
==Characteristics== {| class="wikitable" |- | '''Base:''' || B9G<ref>{{cite web|title=Base B9G|url=http://www.r-type.org/static/baseb9g.htm|accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref> |- | '''Heater:''' || 6.3V/0.3A |- | '''Grid-anode capacitance:''' || 0.007pF |- | '''Transconductance:''' || 6.5mA/V @ I<sub>a</sub>=10mA, I<sub>g2</sub>=3mA, V<sub>a</sub>=250V, V<sub>g2</sub>=250V |}
==Equivalents== To meet great wartime demand the EF50 was also made by [[Marconi-Osram Valve|Marconi-Osram]] (with the name Z90) and [[A.C. Cossor|Cossor]] (their version named 63SPT) in the United Kingdom as well as Mullard (who were effectively using the Philips production line after it was moved from Holland). Versions were also made in Canada by [[Rogers Vacuum Tube Company]] and in the United States by [[Sylvania Electric Products]].
British military (Ministry of Aircraft Production Specification) and U.S. JAN type numbers assigned to the EF50 include: * '''ARP35''' (Army Receiving Pentode 35) * '''VR91''' (Original A.M. Name) * '''CV1091''' (from 1943) * '''ZA3058''' (Army) * '''ZC1051''' or '''ZC/10E/92''' (Army) * '''10E/92''' (Air Ministry)<ref>{{cite web|title=1946 CV Register – A 316|url=http://www.tubecollector.org/cv/1946/cv1072-1099.pdf|accessdate=7 June 2014|location=TABLE I|page=34|date=9 August 1946}}</ref>
The tube was also assigned the GPO ('''PO''')'''VT-207''' type number, VT-250, and CV1578.<ref>[http://www.radiomuseum.org/tubes/tube_ef50.html Radio Museum, EF50]</ref>
Valves of similar characteristics were produced with different bases, for example the later EF42 and [[Tube socket#Miniature tubes|9-pin miniature (B9A)]] EF80.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==See also== [http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/153/e/EF50.pdf Mullard EF50 data sheet] {{Electronic components}} {{Thermionic valves}}
[[Category:Vacuum tubes]] [[Category:Philips products]]

revision.text:
'''Electroacoustic phenomena''' arise when [[ultrasound]] propagates through a [[fluid]] containing [[ions]]. The associated particle motion generates [[electric]] signals because ions have [[electric charge]]. This coupling between ultrasound and [[electric field]] is called electroacoustic phenomena. The fluid might be a simple [[Newtonian liquid]], or complex [[heterogeneous]] [[Dispersion (chemistry)|dispersion]], [[emulsion]] or even a porous body. There are several different electroacoustic effects depending on the nature of the fluid.
*[[Ion vibration current]] (IVI) and potential, an [[electric]] signal that arises when an [[acoustic wave]] propagates through a [[Homogeneous (chemistry)|homogeneous]] fluid. *[[Streaming vibration current]] (SVI) and potential, an electric signal that arises when an acoustic wave propagates through a porous body in which the pores are filled with fluid. *[[Colloid vibration current]] (CVI) and potential, an electric signal that arises when ultrasound propagates through a [[heterogeneous]] fluid, such as a [[Dispersion (chemistry)|dispersion]] or [[emulsion]]. *[[Electric sonic amplitude]] (ESA), the inverse of the CVI effect, in which an acoustic field arises when an [[electric field]] propagates through a [[heterogeneous]] fluid.
==Ion vibration current== {{main|Ion vibration current}} Historically, the IVI was the first known electroacoustic effect. It was predicted by Debye in 1933.<ref>Debye.P."A method for the determination of the mass of electrolyte ions"J. Chem. Phys., 1,13-16,1933</ref>
==Streaming vibration current== {{main|Streaming vibration current}} The streaming vibration current was experimentally observed in 1948 by Williams.<ref>Williams.M. " An Electrokinetic Transducer" The review of scientific instruments, 19, 10, 640-646, 1948</ref> A theoretical model was developed some 30 years later by Dukhin and others.<ref>Dukhin, S.S., Mischuk, N.A., Kuz'menko, B.B and Il'in, B.I. "Flow current and potential in a high-frequency acoustic field" Colloid J., 45, 5, 875-881,1983</ref> This effect opens another possibility for characterizing the electric properties of the surfaces in porous bodies. A similar effect can be observed at a non-porous surface, when sound is bounced off at an oblique angle. The incident and reflected waves superimpose to cause oscillatory fluid motion in the plane of the interface, thereby generating an AC streaming current at the frequency of the sound waves.<ref>Glauser, A.R., Robertson P.A., Lowe, C.R., "An electrokinetic sensor for studying immersed surfaces, using focused ultrasound" Sensors Actuators B, 80, 1, 68-82, 2001</ref>
==Double layer compression== The [[electrical double layer]] can be regarded as behaving like a parallel plate capacitor with a compressible dielectric filling. When sound waves induce a local pressure variation, the spacing of the plates varies at the frequency of the excitation, generating an AC displacement current normal to the interface. For practical reasons this is most readily observed at a conducting surface.<ref>F.I. Kukoz, L.A. Kukoz, "The nature of audioelectro-chemical phenomena" Russ. J. Phys. Chem. 36 (1962) pp. 367-369</ref> It is therefore possible to use an electrode immersed in a conducting electrolyte as a microphone, or indeed as a loudspeaker when the effect is applied in reverse.<ref>N. Tankovsky, "Capacitive ultrasound transducer, based on the electrical double layer in electrolytes" J. App. Phys. 87 (2000) pp. 538-542</ref>
==Colloid vibration potential and current== {{main|Colloid vibration current}} Colloid vibration potential measures the AC potential difference generated between two identical relaxed electrodes, placed in the dispersion, if the latter is subjected to an ultrasonic field. When a sound wave travels through a colloidal suspension of particles whose density differs from that of the surrounding medium, inertial forces induced by the vibration of the suspension give rise to a motion of the charged particles relative to the liquid, causing an alternating electromotive force. The manifestations of this electromotive force may be measured, depending on the relation between the impedance of the suspension and that of the measuring instrument, either as colloid vibration potential or as ''colloid vibration current''.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Delgado | first1 = A. V. | last2 = González-Caballero | first2 = F. | last3 = Hunter | first3 = R.J. | last4 = Koopal | first4 = L.K. | last5 = Lyklem | first5 = J. | title = Measurement and Interpretation of Electrokinetic Phenomena | journal = Pure Appl. Chem. | volume = 77 | issue = 10 | pages = 1753–1805 | url = | jstor = | issn = | doi = 10.1351/pac200577101753 | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | year = 2005 }}</ref>
Colloid vibration potential and current was first reported by Hermans and then independently by Rutgers in 1938. It is widely used for characterizing the ζ-potential of various dispersions and emulsions. The effect, theory, experimental verification and multiple applications are discussed in the book by Dukhin and Goetz.<ref>{{cite book |last=Dukhin |first=A.S. |authorlink= |author2=Goetz, P.J. |title=Ultrasound for Characterizing Colloids |accessdate=2007-10-03 |date=2002 |publisher=[[Elsevier]] |pages=153 |chapter=Electroacoustic Theory |chapterurl=http://www.dispersion.com/pages/theory/electroacoustictheory/electoracoustictheory.html |quote= |ref= }}</ref>
==Electric sonic amplitude== {{main|Electric sonic amplitude}} Electric sonic amplitude was experimentally discovered by Cannon with co-authors in early 1980s.<ref>Oja, T., Petersen, G., and Cannon, D. "Measurement of Electric-Kinetic Properties of a Solution", US Patent 4,497,208,1985</ref> It is also widely used for characterizing ζ-potential in dispersions and emulsions. There is review of this effect theory, experimental verification and multiple applications published by Hunter.<ref>Hunter, R.J. "Review. Recent developments in the electroacoustic characterization of colloidal suspensions and emulsions", Colloids and Surfaces, 141, 37-65, 1998</ref>
==Theory of CVI and ESA== With regard to the theory of CVI and ESA, there was an important observation made by O'Brien,<ref>O'Brien, R.W. "Electro-acoustic effects in a dilute suspension of spherical particles" J. Fluid Mech., 190, 71-86,1988</ref> who linked these measured parameters with [[dynamic electrophoretic mobility]] μ<sub>d</sub>.
:<math> \ CVI(ESA) = A\phi\mu_d\frac{\rho_p-\rho_m}{\rho_m}</math>
where : A is calibration constant, depending on frequency, but not particles properties; : ρ<sub>''p''</sub> is particle density, : ρ<sub>''m''</sub> density of the fluid, : φ is volume fraction of dispersed phase,
Dynamic electrophoretic mobility is similar to [[electrophoretic mobility]] that appears in [[electrophoresis]] theory. They are identical at low frequencies and/or for sufficiently small particles.
There are several theories of the dynamic electrophoretic mobility. Their overview is given in the Ref.5. Two of them are the most important.
The first one corresponds to the Smoluchowski limit. It yields following simple expression for CVI for sufficiently small particles with negligible CVI frequency dependence:
:<math> \ CVI(ESA) = A\phi\frac{\varepsilon_0\varepsilon_m\zeta\Kappa_s}{\eta\Kappa_m}\frac{\rho_p-\rho_s}{\rho_s}</math>
where: : ε<sub>''0''</sub> is vacuum dielectric permittivity, : ε<sub>''m''</sub> is fluid dielectric permittivity, : ζ is [[electrokinetic potential]] : η is dynamic viscosity of the fluid, : K<sub>''s''</sub> is conductivity of the system, : K<sub>''m''</sub> is conductivity of the fluid, : ρ<sub>''s''</sub> is density of the system.
This remarkably simple equation has same wide range of applicability as Smoluchowski equation for [[electrophoresis]]. It is independent on shape of the particles, their concentration.
Validity of this equation is restricted with the following two requirements.
First, it is valid only for a thin [[Double layer (interfacial)|double layer]], when the [[Debye length]] is much smaller than particle's radius a: :<math> {\kappa}a >> 1</math>
Secondly, it neglects the contribution of the [[surface conductivity]]. This assumes a small [[Dukhin number]]: :<math> Du << 1</math>
Restriction of the thin double layer limits applicability of this Smoluchowski type theory only to aqueous systems with sufficiently large particles and not very low ionic strength. This theory does not work well for nano-colloids, including proteins and polymers at low ionic strength. It is not valid for low- or non-polar fluids.
There is another theory that is applicable for the other extreme case of a thick double layer, when :<math> {\kappa}a < 1</math>
This theory takes into consideration the double layer overlap that inevitably occurs for concentrated systems with thick double layer. This allows introduction of so-called "quasi-homogeneous" approach, when overlapped diffuse layers of particles cover the complete interparticle space. The theory becomes much simplified in this extreme case, as shown by Shilov and others.<ref>Shilov, V.N., Borkovskaya, Y.B. and Dukhin A.S. "Electroacoustic theory for concentrated colloids with overlapped DLs at arbitrary ka. Application to nanocolloids and nonaqueous colloids". JCIS, 277, 347-358 (2004)</ref> Their derivation predicts that surface charge density σ is a better parameter than ζ-potential for characterizing electroacoustic phenomena in such systems. An expression for CVI simplified for small particles follows:
:<math> \ CVI = A\frac{2{\sigma}a}{3\eta}\frac{\phi}{1-\phi}\frac{\rho_p-\rho_s}{\rho_s}</math>
==See also== *[[Interface and colloid science]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |last=Dukhin |first=Andrei S. |authorlink= |author2=Philip J. Goetz |title=Ultrasound for Characterizing Colloids |accessdate=2007-10-03 |date=2002 |publisher=Elsevier |pages=153 |chapter=Electroacoustic Theory |chapterurl=http://www.dispersion.com/pages/theory/electroacoustictheory/electoracoustictheory.html }}
[[Category:Chemical mixtures]] [[Category:Colloidal chemistry]] [[Category:Condensed matter physics]] [[Category:Matter]] [[Category:Soft matter]]

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Very long, low frequency waves found near the equator" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Very long, low frequency waves found near the equator}} {{main|Rossby wave }}
'''Equatorial Rossby waves''', often called planetary waves, are very long, low frequency waves found near the equator and are derived using the equatorial beta plane approximation.
==Mathematics==
Using the equatorial beta plane approximation, <math>f = \beta y</math>, where ''β'' is the variation of the [[Coriolis parameter]] with latitude, <math>\beta = \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}</math>. With this approximation, the [[primitive equations]] become the following:
* the continuity equation (accounting for the effects of horizontal convergence and divergence and written with geopotential height):
::<math>\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial t} + c^2 \left ( \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} + \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} \right ) = 0</math>
* the U-momentum equation (zonal component):
::<math>\frac{du}{dt} - v \beta y = -\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial x}</math>
* the V-momentum equation (meridional component):
::<math>\frac{dv}{dt} + u \beta y = -\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial y}.</math><ref name="Holton">Holton, James R., 2004: ''An Introduction to Dynamic Meteorology.'' Elsevier Academic Press, Burlington, MA, pp. 394–400.</ref>
In order to fully linearize the primitive equations, one must assume the following solution:
::<math> \begin{Bmatrix}u, v, \varphi \end{Bmatrix} = \begin{Bmatrix}\hat \varphi \end{Bmatrix} e^{i(k x + \ell y - \omega t)}. </math>
Upon linearization, the primitive equations yield the following dispersion relation:
<math>\omega = -\beta k/(k^2 + (2n + 1)\beta/c)</math>, where ''c'' is the phase speed of an equatorial Kelvin wave (<math>c^2 = g H</math>).<ref name="Gill">Gill, Adrian E., 1982: ''Atmosphere-Ocean Dynamics,'' International Geophysics Series, Volume 30, Academic Press, 662 pp.</ref> Their frequencies are much lower than that of [[gravity waves]] and represent motion that occurs as a result of the undisturbed [[potential vorticity]] varying (not constant) with latitude on the curved surface of the earth. For very long waves (as the zonal wavenumber approaches zero), the non-dispersive phase speed is approximately:
<math>\omega/k = -c/(2n + 1)</math>, which indicates that these long equatorial Rossby waves move in the opposite direction (westward) of Kelvin waves (which move eastward) with speeds reduced by factors of 3, 5, 7, etc. To illustrate, suppose c = 2.8 m/s for the first baroclinic mode in the Pacific; then the Rossby wave speed would correspond to ~0.9 m/s, requiring a 6-month time frame to cross the Pacific basin from east to west.<ref name ="Gill" /> For very short waves (as the zonal wavenumber increases), the group velocity (energy packet) is eastward and opposite to the phase speed, both of which are given by the following relations:
*Frequency relation:
:: <math>\omega = -\beta/k, \, </math>
*Group velocity:
:: <math>c_g = \beta/k^2.</math><ref name="Gill" />
Thus, the phase and group speeds are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction (phase speed is westward and group velocity is eastward); note that is often useful to use [[potential vorticity]] as a tracer for these planetary waves, due to its invertibility (especially in the quasi-geostrophic framework). Therefore, the physical mechanism responsible for the propagation of these equatorial Rossby waves is none other than the conservation of potential vorticity:
::<math>\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\frac{\beta y + \zeta}{H} = 0.</math><ref name="Gill" />
Thus, as a fluid parcel moves equatorward (βy approaches zero), the relative vorticity must increase and become more cyclonic in nature. Conversely, if the same fluid parcel moves poleward, (βy becomes larger), the relative vorticity must decrease and become more anticyclonic in nature.
As a side note, these equatorial Rossby waves can also be vertically-propagating waves when the [[Brunt–Vaisala frequency]] ([[buoyancy]] frequency) is held constant, ultimately resulting in solutions proportional to <math>e^{i(k x + m z - \omega t)}</math>, where ''m'' is the vertical wavenumber and ''k'' is the zonal wavenumber.
Equatorial Rossby waves can also adjust to equilibrium under gravity in the [[tropics]]; because the planetary waves have frequencies much lower than gravity waves. The adjustment process tends to take place in two distinct stages where the first stage is a rapid change due to the fast propagation of gravity waves, the same as that on an ''f''-plane (Coriolis parameter held constant), resulting in a flow that is close to [[geostrophic]] equilibrium. This stage could be thought of as the mass field adjusting to the wave field (due to the wavelengths being smaller than the [[Rossby_radius_of_deformation|Rossby deformation radius]]. The second stage is one where quasi-geostrophic adjustment takes place by means of planetary waves; this process can be comparable to the wave field adjusting to the mass field (due to the wavelengths being larger than the Rossby deformation radius.<ref name="Holton" />
==See also== *[[Equatorial waves]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Oceanography]]

{{infobox mineral | name = Eskolaite | image = Eskolaite.jpg | imagesize = 260px | alt = | caption = Eskolaite from Russia | category = [[Oxide mineral]]
Hematite group
Corundum structural group | formula = Cr2O3 | strunz = 4.CB.05 | dana = | system = [[Trigonal]] | class = Hexagonal scalenohedral ({{overline|3}} m)
[[H-M symbol]]: ({{overline|3}} 2/m) | symmetry = ''R''{{overline|3}}c | unit cell = a = 4.95, c = 13.58 [Å]; Z = 6 | color = Black to dark green | habit = Hexagonal prisms and plates | twinning = | cleavage = None | fracture = | tenacity = Brittle | mohs = 8 | luster = Vitreous or metallic | streak = Pale green | diaphaneity = Opaque, translucent in thin edges | gravity = 5.18 | density = | polish = | opticalprop = Uniaxial | refractive = | birefringence = | pleochroism = Noted; emerald-green to olive-green | 2V = | dispersion = | extinction = | length fast/slow = | fluorescence = | absorption = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | impurities = | alteration = | other = | references = [http://rruff.info/doclib/hom/eskolaite.pdf Eskolaite in the Handbook of Mineralogy][http://www.mindat.org/min-1411.html Eskolaite on Mindat.org][http://www.webmineral.com/data/Eskolaite.shtml Eskolaite data on Webmineral.com] }} '''Eskolaite''' is an uncommon [[chromium]] [[oxide mineral]] ([[chromium(III) oxide]] Cr2O3). ==Discovery and occurrence== It was first described in 1958 for an occurrence in the [[Outokumpu, Finland|Outokumpu]] ore deposit of eastern [[Finland]]. It occurs in chromium bearing [[tremolite]] [[skarn]]s, [[metamorphosed]] [[quartzite]]s and [[Chlorite group|chlorite]] bearing [[Vein (geology)|veins]] in Finland; in [[Glacier|glacial]] boulder clays in [[Ireland]] and in stream pebbles in the [[Merume River]] of [[Guyana]]. It has also been recognized as a rare component in [[chondrite meteorite]]s. The mineral is named after the Finnish geologist [[Pentti Eskola]] (1883–1964). ==Structure and physical properties== [[Image:Eskolaite-pV.svg|thumb|250 px|left|Molar volume vs. pressure at room temperature.]] Eskolaite crystallizes with trigonal symmetry in the space group ''R''{{overline|3}}''c'' and has the lattice parameters a = 4.95 Å and c = 13.58 Å at standard conditions. The unit cell contains six formula units. The lattice is analogous to that of [[corundum]], with Cr3+ replacing Al3+. {{clear|left}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Chromium minerals]] [[Category:Oxide minerals]] [[Category:Trigonal minerals]] [[Category:Hematite group]] {{oxide-mineral-stub}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Freezing rain}}
{{Weather}}
'''Freezing drizzle''' is [[drizzle]] that freezes on contact with the ground or an object at or near the surface. Its [[METAR]] code is '''FZDZ'''.<ref name="Spence2006">{{cite book|last1=Spence|first1=Charles F.|title=Aim/Far|date=2006|publisher=[[McGraw Hill Professional]]|isbn=9780071479240|page=294|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h0vp1WORkJEC&q=%22freezing+drizzle%22&dq=%22freezing+drizzle%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwit9-vrqezWAhVR-lQKHTpEAxkQ6AEIRTAF|accessdate=13 October 2017|language=en}}</ref>
==Formation== Although freezing drizzle and [[freezing rain]] are similar in that they both involve liquid precipitation at the surface during subfreezing temperatures, the mechanisms leading to their development are entirely different. Where freezing rain forms when frozen precipitation falls through a melting layer, freezing drizzle forms via the ''supercooled warm rain process'' in which cloud droplets coalesce until they become heavy enough to fall out of the cloud.<ref name=severe>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9_8YLgEACAAJ&dq=severe+%26+hazardous+weather|title=Severe & Hazardous Weather|isbn=9780757597725|author1=Rauber|first1=Robert M|last2=Walsh|first2=John E|last3=Charlevoix|first3=Donna Jean|year=2012}}</ref> Despite this process taking place in a subfreezing environment, the liquid water will not freeze if the environmental temperature is above {{convert|18|°F|°C}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.weather.gov/lot/2015jan26 |title=Freezing Drizzle on January 26th; A Look Into Why |website=National Weather Service |access-date=10 December 2017}}</ref> If [[ice crystals]] are already present in this environment, the liquid droplets will freeze onto these crystals and be effectively removed before they can grow large enough to fall out of the cloud. As a result, freezing drizzle develops in shallow [[stratus cloud|stratus-type]] clouds where saturation occurs entirely below the layer in which ice crystals can develop and grow.<ref name=severe></ref>
==Effects== When freezing drizzle accumulates on land it creates an icy layer of [[glaze ice|glaze]]. Freezing drizzle alone does not generally result in significant [[ice]] accumulations due to its light, low-intensity nature. However, even thin layers of slick ice deposited on roads as [[black ice]] can cause extremely hazardous conditions resulting in vehicle crashes.
Freezing drizzle is extremely dangerous to aircraft as the supercooled water droplets will freeze onto the airframe, degrading aircraft performance considerably. The loss of [[American Eagle Flight 4184]] on October 31, 1994 has been attributed to ice buildup due to freezing drizzle aloft.<ref name=severe></ref>
==See also== * [[Black ice]] * [[Freezing rain]]
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Freezing Drizzle}} [[Category:Precipitation]] [[Category:Weather hazards]]
{{climate-stub}}
[[ja:雨氷]]

{{short description|Set of names from Greek mythology}} {{For|the moth|Glauce (moth){{!}}''Glauce'' (moth)}} In [[Greek mythology]], '''Glauce''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɡ|l|ɔː|s|iː}}; Ancient Greek: Γλαυκή "blue-gray" or "gleaming"), [[Latin]] '''Glauca''', refers to different people:
*Glauce, twin sister of [[Pluto_(mythology)#Euhemerism_and_Latinization|Pluto]] who died as an infant according to [[Euhemerus]].<ref>[[Lactantius]], ''Institutiones Divinae'', 1. 14. 5, citing [[Ennius]]</ref> *Glauce, an [[Arcadia]]n [[nymph]], one of the nurses of [[Zeus]].<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 8. 47. 3</ref> *Glauce, one of the [[Nereids]].<ref>[[Homer]], ''Iliad'', 18. 39</ref><ref>[[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'', 244</ref><ref>[[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'', Preface</ref> *Glauce, one of the [[Meliae|Melia]]n nymphs.<ref>[[Tzetzes]] on ''Theogony'', 101</ref> *Glauce, mother, by Upis, of "the third" [[Artemis]] in [[Cicero]]'s rationalized genealogy of the Greek gods.<ref>Cicero, ''[[De natura deorum]]'', 3. 23</ref> *Glauce, one of the [[Danaids]], daughter of [[Danaus]]. She married Alces, son of [[Aegyptus]] and an Arabian woman.<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 2. 1. 5</ref> *[[Creusa (daughter of Creon)|Glauce]], daughter of [[Creon (king of Corinth)|Creon]]. She married [[Jason]]. She was killed, along with her father, by [[Medea]], who either sent her a [[peplos]] steeped in flammable poison or set fire to the royal palace.<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 1. 9. 28</ref><ref>[[Diodorus Siculus]], ''Library of History'', 4. 54. 2 - 6</ref> In the local [[Corinth]]ian tradition, Glauce threw herself into a well in a vain attempt to wash off Medea's poison; from this circumstance the well became known as the Well of Glauce.<ref>[[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]], ''Description of Greece'', 2. 3. 6</ref> Also known by the name [[Creusa]], predominantly in Latin authors, e.g. Seneca (''Medea'') and Propertius (2.16.30). [[Hyginus]] (Fab. 25) uses both names interchangeably. In [[Cherubini|Cherubini's]] [[opera]] [[Médée (Cherubini)| Medea]] she is known as Dircé. *Glauce, an [[Amazons|Amazon]].<ref>[[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'', 163</ref> Some say that it was she, and not [[Antiope (Amazon)|Antiope]], who was abducted by [[Theseus]] and became his wife.<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'', Epitome of Book 4, 5. 2</ref><ref>[[Scholia]] on ''[[Iliad]]'', 3. 189</ref> *Glauce, daughter of [[Cychreus]], son of [[Poseidon]] and [[Salamis (mythology)|Salamis]]. Some sources say that Glauce married Actaeus and bore him a son [[Telamon]].<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' 3. 12. 6 with reference to [[Pherecydes of Leros|Pherecydes]]</ref> Others say that Telamon was her husband and that, after her death, he married [[Periboea]], mother of [[Ajax the Great|Ajax]].<ref>[[Diodorus Siculus]], ''Library of History'', 4. 72. 7</ref> *Glauce, daughter of [[Cycnus]], sister of Cobis and Corianus. During the Trojan campaign, she was taken captive by the Greeks and was given to [[Ajax the Great|Ajax]],<ref>[[Dictys Cretensis]], 2. 13</ref> by whom she became mother of Aeantides.<ref>Dictys Cretensis, 5. 16</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}{{Greek myth index}} [[Category:Women in Greek mythology]] [[Category:Amazons (Greek mythology)]] [[Category:Nymphs]] [[Category:Nereids]]

revision.comment: hatnote for HZE
revision.text:
{{Redirect|HZE|the aiport with this designation|Mercer County Regional Airport}} '''HZE ions''' are the high-energy [[Atomic nucleus|nuclei]] component of [[galactic cosmic ray]]s (GCRs) which have an [[electric charge]] greater than +2. The abbreviation "HZE" comes from high (H) [[atomic number]] (Z) and [[energy]] (E). HZE ions include the nuclei of all [[Chemical element|elements]] heavier than [[hydrogen]] (which has a +1 charge) and [[helium]] (which has a +2 charge). Each HZE ion consists of a nucleus with no orbiting [[electron]]s, meaning that the charge on the [[ion]] is the same as the atomic number of the nucleus.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
HZE ions are rare compared to [[protons]], for example, composing only 1% of GCRs versus 85% for protons.<ref name="Schimmerling">{{cite web|url=https://three.jsc.nasa.gov/concepts/SpaceRadiationEnviron.pdf|title=The Space Radiation Environment: An Introduction|last=Schimmerling|first=Walter|date=5 February 2011|publisher=Universities Space Research Association Division of Space Life Sciences|access-date=8 January 2013|work=The Health Risks of Extraterrestrial Environments}}</ref> HZE ions, like other GCRs, travel near the [[speed of light]]. Their source is likely to be [[supernova]] explosions.<ref name="Mars">[https://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2004/17feb_radiation Can People go to Mars?] Science@NASA, February 17, 2004.</ref>
In addition to the HZE ions from cosmic sources, HZE ions are produced by the [[Sun]]. During [[solar flare]]s and other solar storms, HZE ions are sometimes produced in small amounts along with the more typical protons,<ref name="NASA/TP-1999-209320" /> but their energy level is substantially smaller than HZE ions from [[cosmic ray]]s.<ref name=Mars />
[[Space radiation]] is composed mostly of high-energy [[protons]], [[helium]] nuclei, and high-Z high-energy ions (HZE ions). The ionization patterns in [[molecule]]s, [[cell (biology)|cells]], [[Tissue (biology)|tissues]], and the resulting biological harm are distinct from high-energy [[photon]] radiation—[[x-ray]]s and [[gamma ray]]s, which produce low-[[linear energy transfer]] (low-LET) radiation from [[secondary electrons]]. While in [[space]], [[astronaut]]s are exposed to protons, helium nuclei, and HZE ions, as well as [[secondary radiation]] from [[nuclear reaction]]s from [[spacecraft]] parts or tissue.<ref name="122-123">{{cite web |last=Cucinotta|first=F.A. |last2=Durante|first2=M. |title=Risk of Radiation Carcinogenesis |url=http://humanresearchroadmap.nasa.gov/evidence/reports/Carcinogenesis.pdf |work=Human Health and Performance Risks of Space Exploration Missions Evidence reviewed by the NASA Human Research Program |publisher=NASA |accessdate=6 June 2012 |pages=122–123}}</ref>
Prominent HZE ions: * [[Carbon|Carbon (C)]] * [[Oxygen|Oxygen (O)]] * [[Magnesium|Magnesium (Mg)]] * [[Silicon|Silicon (Si)]] * [[Iron|Iron (Fe)]] GCRs typically originate from outside the [[Solar System]] and within the [[Milky Way|Milky Way galaxy]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Galactic Cosmic Rays|url=http://helios.gsfc.nasa.gov/gcr.html|publisher=NASA|accessdate=6 June 2012}}</ref> but those from outside of the Milky Way consist mostly of highly energetic protons with a small component of HZE ions.<ref name=122-123 /> GCR energy spectra peaks, with median energy peaks up to 1,000 [[Electronvolt|MeV]]/[[atomic mass unit|amu]], and nuclei (with energies up to 10,000 [[Electronvolt|MeV]]/[[atomic mass unit|amu]]) are important contributors to the dose equivalent.<ref name=122-123 />
==Health concerns of HZE ions== {{main|Health threat from cosmic rays}} Although HZE ions make up a small proportion of cosmic rays, their high charge and high energies cause them to contribute significantly to the overall biological impact of cosmic rays, making them as significant as protons in regard to biological impact.<ref name="Schimmerling" /> The most dangerous GCRs are heavy ionized nuclei such as Fe +26, an [[iron (element)|iron]] nucleus with a charge of +26. Such heavy particles are "much more energetic (millions of [[MeV]]) than typical protons accelerated by solar flares (tens to hundreds of MeV)."<ref name=Mars /> HZE ions can therefore penetrate through thick layers of shielding and body tissue, "breaking the strands of DNA molecules, damaging genes and killing cells."<ref name=Mars />
For HZE ions that originate from [[solar particle event]]s (SPEs), there is only a small contribution toward a person's [[absorbed dose]] of radiation. During a SPE, there is such a small amount of heavy ions generated that their effects are limited. Their energies per [[atomic mass unit]] are all significantly less than protons found in the same SPE, meaning that protons are by far the largest contribution to astronaut body exposure during SPEs.<ref name="NASA/TP-1999-209320">[http://hdl.handle.net/2060/19990051001 Contribution of High Charge and Energy (HZE) Ions During Solar-Particle Event of September 29, 1989] Kim, Myung-Hee Y.; Wilson, John W.; Cucinotta, Francis A.; Simonsen, Lisa C.; Atwell, William; Badavi, Francis F.; Miller, Jack, NASA Johnson Space Center; Langley Research Center, May 1999.</ref>
==See also== *[[High energy nuclear physics]] *[[Ionizing radiation#Cosmic radiation|Cosmic radiation]] *[[Solar energetic particles]] *[[Spaceflight radiation carcinogenesis]] *[[Central nervous system effects from radiation exposure during spaceflight]] - HZE CNS health effects *[[Swift heavy ion]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/linear+energy+transfer Low-LET Radiation - The Free Dictionary]
[[Category:Subatomic particles]] [[Category:Cosmic rays]]

{{Infobox feature on Mars |name = Home Plate |image = [[Image:PIA09089-RA3-hirise-closeup annotated.png|200px]] |caption = [[HiRISE]] image of the "Home Plate" [[rock outcrop]]. |type = [[Rock outcrop]] |coordinates = {{coord|14.6|S|175.5|E|globe:mars_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} }} '''Home Plate''' is a plateau roughly 90 m across within the [[Columbia Hills (Mars)|Columbia Hills]], [[Mars]]. It is informally named for its similarity in shape to a [[baseball]] [[home plate]]. Home Plate is a rocky outcrop that appears to show layered feature.
The plateau has been extensively studied by [[Spirit rover|''Spirit'']], one of the [[Mars Exploration Rover]]s, since 2006. The rover became stuck in loose granular material alongside the northeast side of the plateau. The rover last communicated with Earth on March 22, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/mer/multimedia/pia15037.html|title=Spirit Remains Silent at Troy|accessdate=April 21, 2012}}</ref>
==Exploration== ''Spirit'' arrived at Home Plate on [[Timekeeping on Mars|sol]] 744 (February 7, 2006) and has completed a scientific investigation with her robotic arm before moving to Low Ridge Haven due to power concerns. She returned on sol 1126 to resume those studies.
''Spirit'' spent her third Martian winter on Home Plate's north edge.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn12884-mars-rover-spirit-to-head-north-for-the-winter.html|title=Mars rover Spirit to head north for the winter|author=Maggie McKee|accessdate=December 26, 2007}}</ref> {{Wide image|Sol594A P2281 L257atc-A597R1 br2.jpg|600px|Home Plate (upper center), as seen from the summit of Husband Hill.}} ==Origins== Scientists now believe that Home Plate is an explosive volcanic deposit. It is surrounded by deposits of [[basalt]], which are believed to have exploded on contact with water. The presence of brine is further supported by the high concentration of [[chloride ion]]s in the surrounding rocks. The presence of [[bomb sag]]s (laminae typically found in beds of volcanish ash) seems to confirm this hypothesis.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]]|title=Pyroclastic Activity at Home Plate in Gusev Crater, Mars|pages=738–742|volume=316|doi=10.1126/science.1139045|date=2007|pmid=17478719|issue=5825|bibcode = 2007Sci...316..738S |last2=Aharonson|first2=O.|last3=Clark|first3=B.C.|last4=Cohen|first4=B. A.|last5=Crumpler|first5=L.|last6=De Souza|first6=P. A.|last7=Farrand|first7=W. H.|last8=Gellert|first8=R.|last9=Grant|first9=J.|last10=Grotzinger|first10=J. P.|last11=Haldemann|first11=A. F. C.|last12=Johnson|first12=J. R.|last13=Klingelhofer|first13=G.|last14=Lewis|first14=K. W.|last15=Li|first15=R.|last16=McCoy|first16=T.|last17=McEwen|first17=A. S.|last18=McSween|first18=H. Y.|last19=Ming|first19=D. W.|last20=Moore|first20=J. M.|last21=Morris|first21=R. V.|last22=Parker|first22=T. J.|last23=Rice|first23=J. W.|last24=Ruff|first24=S.|last25=Schmidt|first25=M.|last26=Schroder|first26=C.|last27=Soderblom|first27=L. A.|last28=Yen|first28=A.|last1=Squyres|first1=S.|authorlink1=Steve Squyres}}</ref>
A patch of 90% pure [[opal]]ine [[silicon dioxide]] was unearthed by ''Spirit'' in the vicinity of Home Plate. The patch is believed to be formed in acidic [[Hot spring|hydrothermal conditions]], which supports the theory that Home Plate is of an explosive volcanic origin. Water is also present as mineral [[hydrate]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/mer/mer-20070521.html|title=Mars Rover Spirit Unearths Surprise Evidence of Wetter Past|accessdate=May 30, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Science|volume=320|pages=1063–1067|author=Squyres, et al.|title=Detection of Silica-Rich Deposits on Mars|doi=10.1126/science.1155429|date=2008|pmid=18497295|issue=5879|last2=Arvidson|first2=RE|last3=Ruff|first3=S|last4=Gellert|first4=R|last5=Morris|first5=RV|last6=Ming|first6=DW|last7=Crumpler|first7=L|last8=Farmer|first8=JD|last9=Marais|first9=DJ|last10=Yen|first10=A.|last11=McLennan|first11=S. M.|last12=Calvin|first12=W.|last13=Bell|first13=J. F.|last14=Clark|first14=B. C.|last15=Wang|first15=A.|last16=McCoy|first16=T. J.|last17=Schmidt|first17=M. E.|last18=De Souza|first18=P. A.|bibcode = 2008Sci...320.1063S |display-authors=8}}</ref>
Since 2008, scientists believe that this formation is an example of an eroded, ancient, and extinct [[fumarole]].<ref>The Hydrothermal System at Home Plate in Gusev Crater, Mars, R.V.Morris, S.W.Squyres, -et al., Lunar & Planetary Science XXXIX(2008)</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery class="center"> File:Home plate.JPG|''Spirit'' imager moves towards Home Plate. File:Bomb sag on Mars.jpg|Bomb sag at Home Plate. File:Home plate anim.gif|Curious rock, "animated" via [[wiggle stereoscopy]]. </gallery>
==See also== {{wikinews|Spirit Rover on Mars finds water made 'silica-rich soil'}} * [[List of rocks on Mars]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links==
*[http://mars.jpl.nasa.gov/ Nasa's Mars Exploration Program] *[http://marsrovers.nasa.gov/mission/traverse_maps.html Current position of the Mars rovers] - Home Plate is visible, with ''Spirit''{{'}}s journey around it. *[http://www.planetary.org/blog/article/00000452/ The Planetary Society Weblog: Home, Sweet Home for ''Spirit''] *[http://marsrovers.jpl.nasa.gov/ Official Mars Rovers site]
{{MarsRocks}} {{Mars}} {{portal bar|Mars}}
